ratings.question_text: What percentage of the reading and other assignments did you complete?

narratives.question_text: How well was the course organized?
comments: I know that many of us offered constructive criticism on the form for Drama 6A. That feedback was not taken into account. As you can imagine, this makes me reluctant to spend the time outlining what is and isn't working once again. The current design of this class is not up to YSD standards.
This class is organized from a Eurocentric perspective. This is problematic.
Keeping everything up to date on the v2 server was very useful.
The powerpoints are interesting but do not follow the lecture so it sometimes becomes a distraction rather than an aid to the class.
Paul Walsh's portion was excellent, the T.A.'s on the other hand seemed nervous and unorganized.
The class structure and curriculum was organized and never wavered from that standard. Even when snow days shook the schedule, a new schedule was created and administered immediately.

narratives.question_text: How effective was the balance between instruction and discussion?
comments: It is a lecture class so I understand
The lectures are sped through and the slides online are very discombobulated.

It would be very interesting to me to have more discussion rather than lecture time. To be more specific I learned more discussing the topics we were going over in the lectures rather than just taking notes from a powerpoint.
Kee-Yun was an excellent discussion leader and I felt so much more in tune with this semesters lectures as a result
The "sections" allowed for enough time to discuss the lectures.
Kee-Yoon was a WONDERFUL discussion leader. He came to the table with wonderful insights and background knowledge of the readings, and led effectively through necessary dialogue around each topic.

Breakout discussion groups allowed us to examine the material amongst fellow students, however there aren't as many discussion groups as there are lectures so some material wasn't afforded discussion.

narratives.question_text: How well did the assigned papers, reports or other projects reflect the aims of the course?
comments: I feel that the assignments fostered an adequate and thoughtful function for the course.

In an school environment that does not assume previous academic experience, I think it would make sense to structure the projects in a way that best highlights the skill sets of the school's students. Specifically, I think that the paper assignment is geared towards a student with a specific academic background and is therefore not a very sensitive tool with which to measure a student's absorption of the material. Many students spend much more time worrying about how the paper will be crafted (a skill that is most practically useful only to dramaturgs, critics, and perhaps directors) instead of thinking about the material itself. I think a more open ended project, through which the students could engage with the material in a way that corresponds to or overlaps with their own area of expertise, would make the course feel more relevant and less overwhelming.
We arent tested on what we've learned in the class but rather how well we can memorize material for the exams.

The Fuchs paper is a great way to ask students to write that allows a focus on production. It highlights the aim of the course to provide inspiration, rather than lean academic for its many non-academic students.

I enjoyed the play I read for the paper and I was glad to have an easy topic in the middle of such a busy semester but since I pretty much approach every play as described in the Fuch's essay it felt like busy work.

RE the paper, the reality is we have so much to do at this school between course work, homework, production work, production assignments, and workstudy that the paper becomes more of an albatross than an opportunity for learning. It becomes that thing in the way the week you try to do it, and end up pulling an all nighter to fit into our already chaotic lives.
I feel like 2 papers is fair.
The paper for this class not only allowed for deeper study into the world of a particular play, it opened me up to the Elinor Fuchs style of analyzation.

The canon of what is covered in this course is slanted. There is a Euro-centric focus that I think should be evaluated because we miss out on the wealth of theatre history that is not focused on European advancement.

narratives.question_text: How did the amount of assigned reading work with weekly discussion?
comments: The plays were too long. Some weeks I was unable to read the play in time. Plays that take longer than 2 hours to read or require a second read simply get put aside during production weeks.
It's hard to get the readings done with all the work we already have.

Honestly, the amount of assigned reading is the bare minimum that I can give per week. TDs and Designers are unfairly swarmed with crazy schedules that it is just unfortunate that I can only give no more than time to read the text. Earlier in the week I was able to read Oscar Brockett's books and research other materials online, but then things became really really impossible, and some weeks, were simply impossible. Its just unfortunate, because it is such a privilege to receive lectures by Paul Walsh and have break-out discussions by an amazing team of TAs, and I wished we had more time.

The workload is respectable, but sometimes difficult to prioritize with assignments that deal with my focus, or production assignments. What I'm saying is that Drama 6 responses were my lowest priority.
Knowing in advance what the assigned readings were, along with when the discussions were was extremely helpful. The consistency was needed to operate productively and effectively within YSD.

narratives.question_text: How did the supplementary materials (files, videos, recordings, etc.) for the course enhance your experience of it?
comments: I didn't feel like there wasn't much variation in the supplementary material.
I didn't have time to explore the supplementary material.
There should be more use of audio/visual materials in class.
I did not realize we would NEED the supplementary materials as they were all but ignored last semester and suddenly they appeared on the final. We don't have time to keep digging into the class.

I had some trouble looking for some texts (HERNANI for example), and that completely destroyed my schedule, and as a designer, there are some days I just simply cannot work on drama 6 because its impossible with other demands like production and classes, and if I'm caught still looking around for the text at the wrong day, then I'm actually screwed.
Supplementary materials were often helpful, if I was able to find the time to digest them.
The slides aren't very helpful during class, because Paul has to rush through in order to get his lectures in before time is up.

narratives.question_text: The course filled a significant gap in your knowledge of the field.
comments: I loved listening to the lectures and learning some of the background of the work I do.
I had very little theater history background coming into this course.
I now know a great deal about European theater. I can't say the same about any other culture.
My prior knowledge of theater history was full of holes. I have a much better foundation now.
For someone like myself, who hasn't had a theatre history course in 10+ years, this course was very educational.

I knew much of the information from my undergraduate education, and much of the information I came into the class with seemed to be missing. Additionally, I looked forward to learning a lot more than I walked away with. I left the class with a significant gap of knowledge still.

narratives.question_text: Regardless of whether or not the course is required, would you recommend it to other students in and outside the department?
comments: I would recommend it if they are interested in theatre.
YES

From my perspective, the course offers a lot of interesting information, but the assignments pulled me away, or offered unneeded distraction from the coursework that is directly related to my time at this school. When I met with the chair of my department last semester and Drama 6, and my performance in it, was not even mentioned, I felt that there was some institutional schism between my department and the mandated course, or that my department does not truly consider Drama 6 to be part of my essential work at the school. So I tested out. But I still wanted to leave comments because I think this is a valuable class.

Yes. I think it's important that students in all departments keep thinking broadly about performance, and this class helps do that. For students outside the Drama 50 club, I also think it's important that people keep reading plays consistently.
Only if they have an extra 4 hours in their week for all of the reading.

I would recommend it but I believe the work the class entails should not get in the way of the real reason why we are attending this program. It should be catered to the fact that all the different students in the different fields have workloads that don't permit them to absorb the valuable information this class delivers. Things need to be structured in a different way.

No. Unfortunately, I felt as though due to the nature of the way in which the information is spoken at us, one could learn just as much from simply reading a book or the very powerpoint that the professor uses. There is no need for a lecture. Discussion groups were useful.
Yes, I do feel it has a useful place in the course of study.
I would recommend they audit it.There isn't enough time in this school to give the class the time it deserves and not have your other work suffer.
This class is ABSOLUTELY A MUST for all students. I wish we had more time. I really wish we had more time.
While interesting material I would not recommend the class to someone unless they had plenty of time to dedicate to the class. I feel like I would have gotten a lot more out of it if I had more time.

I have told other people that this course was very helpful to me, but if I had recently been a part of a similar course, I would recommend putting the time into a course that aligned more with their concentration.
Yes indeed!

Definitely. Paul Walsh gives a comprehensive oveview on Theatre and its evolution. I was able to draw comparisons between periods into the present and to hypothesize the future of Theatre as well as what I am interested in creating myself. There is a lot of information to cover and not everything peaked my interest which I think could be solved through a survey at the beginning of class allowing students to voice from what perspective they are interested in studying Theatre ki.e. female artists, black artists,lgbtq artists) as to ensure they are included in the class more.

No, because I believe it's a skewed view of Theatre History, and lacks a significant information on the contribution to the inception and evolution of theatre by people of color - specifically on the African continent, reducing the contribution to that of ritual and plays created in response to colonialism.
The knowledge afforded by this course is expansive.

narratives.question_text: The course goals were clearly presented.
comments: If the goal was to learn as much about the progress of theatre as possible in a limited amount of time, then yes, this course provided that.

narratives.question_text: The instructor has a strong grasp of the course subject matter.
comments: I think the viewpoint was very tailored to the teacher's perspective of Theatre history.
I would follow Paul Walsh to hell and back. He not only has a great grasp on the material, he has developed his own unique perspective that I am lucky to have experienced.

What was presented, with the exception of theatrical contributions of Africans and African- Americans, seemed to be very thorough. Additionally, the information that was presented on European contribution to theatre, like Grotowski, his connection and studies with the African and Afro-Carribean content in the development of his theatrical practices and theories were not acknowledged by Paul. I find examples like this, and the formerly mentioned lack of information extremely troubling, because it marginalizes the presences of Blackness in the inception of theatre world that we know and respect. Thomas Richards' book "The Edge Point of Performance" highlights his work with Grotowski and where the man drew great inspiration from. This was one of the books I read this semester researching for an acting class, and discovered this information. I'd have never known about it otherwise. However, learning of this, I was able to appreciate that there was a mixing of cultural contribution to create the work we study and respect, rather than everything having derived from Eurocentric conception. I believe there should be more information to support this idea, and therefore taught, so we can have evidence to support the call for diversity within the theatre. If we see perpetuate the lack of diversity within the historical study, we'll have less support on the modern day end.

narratives.question_text: The instructor presented the subject matter effectively.
comments: I think timeline got screwy somewhere in the middle of the term.

Paul Walsh does a great job of helping his students imagine what historical plays were like in performance. It's hard in a course that has to cover so much material, but sometimes it might be useful to give a little more historical context of what was going on outside the theater that artists were responding to.

Sometimes the essays were too fast to keep up with and the powerpoints have material not covered in the lecture so trying to keep up with both was impossible. I do love the little jokes included to keep us awake though.

My only critque here would be its hard, at 9am, after pulling weeks of nights sleeping 2 to 3 hour a night, to see a slideshow flying by with a lecture racing by and the two things dont necessarily "agree". I understand you are using the slideshow to give us more information - but I miss a LOT of things in class because I am either trying to read the slide or listen to you.

Things got really really confusing, particularly distinguishing different types of romanticism. And also futurism and the rest of the modernist movements. They are so subjective that it is not only difficult to remember. They are also difficult to really grasp. But I am grateful that the lecture and section on Brecht made it so clear for me, because I never understood him. But thanks to Paul Walsh's lecture in clarifying that Brecht and what makes a production 'Brechtian' was not simply attributed to his 'estrangement' techniques, but also dramaturgically embedded in his text and others. Brilliant. But I still don't find Brecht too fancy.
Delivering lectures week after week to a group of "kids" that often show up late and seem disinterested is a special challenge, and Paul handles it with grace and humor.
With the exception of a few rushed lectures.
So much information was fit into each lecture that they all whizzed by, often making it difficult to get a sufficient grasp of all the material.

narratives.question_text: The instructor was willing to consider diverse points of view.
comments: I do feel that we are missing a large part of minority voices in our history lessons.
If it wasn't geared towards Europeans, the instructor wasn't willing to venture out.

Paul Walsh is conscientious about representing a diversity of histories and traditions in his class, and he is responsive to the students' requests for more. Learning about many cultures is a lifelong task for everyone, and he should continue to push the course to be better and better in this regard.
Covering plays from other continents was great.

On occasion a question would be raised about an opinion presented. Dr. Walsh would almost certainly research the subject more and clarify the response in a later course. He has no ego when it comes to learning.

Again, there was an absence of discussion around female artists band writers as well as those of color. I wanted to see less male white writer s although I understand those writers were the ones being produced most. I think talking about a few less famous but unique and revolutionary writers would be more beneficial and expand what we perceive theatre's past is and what the future can be.

Not thoroughly - meaning, diverse points of views were acknowledge based on our comments or calls for them, however, they significantly lacked the depth with the exception of European and Chinese perspectives.

There were excuses made when it came time to cover theatre history outside of the Euro-centric canon. Things like lack of resources, knowledge, and time on the subject were cited as the reason why we were not learning about it. I can't believe that this is the case at Yale School of Drama. We must be more inclusive in our study of what has come before.

narratives.question_text: The instructor was willing to answer pertinent questions.
comments: Given the time constraints prof. Walsh did his best.
I wish he always left time for questions at the end

Often, questions of diversity of his lecture perspective would be answered defensively or sarcastically. For example, a classmate asked a question asking about the role of the Harlem Renaissance and the Black Theatre Movement in relation to a lecture Paul gave that happened during that time period, and he answered, "you mean, like the contribution of people like Langston Hughes and Lorraine Hansberry?" - two Black people he'd briefly mentioned in his lecture, as to say that he had serviced her request. He failed to answer her question, and I believe the point that was missed was that, those two people don't represent and entire movements that spanned decades, and the mere mention of them, was what my classmate was asking for or about. The defensive demeanor by Paul was very discouraging, and after witnessing, I didn't feel welcomed to engage him with questions of the sort.

narratives.question_text: The grading criteria was clearly explained.
comments: the exams were graded by TAs and feel like there is a fairly large variance between the grading.
It seemed to me that if you did the work and showed up, you would be fine.

narratives.question_text: The instructor was available for consultation, discussion and advice.
comments: Always open to chat.

I am entirely grateful to Ilinca this spring for her patience, and understanding, and always being available even at the last minute. Being last minute is never pleasant, and as grown ups we know it isn't nice. But some weeks in YSD just makes things impossible to happen, and unfortunately a great class like drama 6 has to become 'secondary' in our list of a million priorities. That's my greatest regret, having a designer's schedule, is not being able to perform as a great drama 6 student.

narratives.question_text: I would recommend this instructor to other students.
comments: Paul Walsh has got our backs. He made himself totally available.
Always had an interesting perspective.

narratives.question_text: How many of the 14 class meetings did you attend?  Comments:
comments: I missed two classes.
I attended all meeting except for one because of a scheduled assignment.
All.
11? I think.
All of them.
Dont recall.
All in the exception of when I was sick.
I believe 11. I was excused for all of my absences.
All but 3.
I attended all class meetings and discussion sessions.

narratives.question_text: Please offer additional comments you have on such topics as: what worked best about the course, what improvements you would suggest, etc.
comments: I found it frustrating in the final exam when we were expected to know plays that we did not read for this course (plays that were mentioned in lectures but not really discussed) There is barely time to learn the material covered. There is no time to do any extracurricular reading. If we had been able to discuss plays within our knowledge base that were not discussed it would have been better than having been asked about very specific plays that I did not know.

I would desperately beg that the material and the history being presented in class was not so white, european centric. There was a LOT of history that was either unspoken of or just barely skimmed over. I do realize that it is impossible to cover everything in this one class BUT I think it is extremely irresponsible of this institution to give less weight and importance to movements such as The Harlem Renaissance, or The Chicano Movement, or the LGBT Movement, among others. There is such emphasis on the canonized history of the theater, but the canon is not necessarily the best representative of the collective historical progression that has led to where and how the theater exists today. We need to be more responsible. This is not a condemnation of the professor. This is a call to arms. Priorities need to be made and met.
As I said above...less from the white make perspective on Theatre.

narratives.question_text: How would you rate the overall usefulness of discussion sections for this class?
comments: To help create opportunities for grading, and to encourage the students to engage with the matieral closely, I think that students should be asked to lead the discussion sections once or twice during the semester. They would send out questions to think about at the beginning of the week, come into class with a short (2-3 minute) presentation of some aspect of the text that interested them and connects to the questions they asked, and then lead their fellow students in discussion. I think this might be a good idea too, because public speaking and clear explanation of ideas and moderation of discussion applies across disciplines -- its a skill that can be used effectively or not so in production meetings, meet and greets, rehearsal rooms, etc.
Discussion sections are extremely useful.
Discussion groups were invaluable.
I feel like one term was more beneficial than the other - based on the TA and the percentage of students who had done the readings.

I enjoyed my discussion leader, and i was one of the more vocal members of my section. I find that the usefulness of these periods is due to my fellow students, much more than the T.A. Their divergent and vocal opinions create a great discussion.

narratives.question_text: Was enough time devoted to discussion sections?
comments: More discussion time. Helps a lot. Learn a lot more from the discussion than just taking notes.

narratives.question_text: Did you attend all the discussions?
comments: Yes
Yes
Yes.
Yes
No, I missed 2.
Yes.
I missed 1 or 2
Yes.
Yes.
Yes
Yes
I believe I missed one. Again excused.
Yes
All but 2
All, but 2.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: Did you find the discussion leader effective and prepared?
comments: Instructor: Ilinca Tamara Todorut  She was not my TA -- I didnt take the class this semester -- but I wasn't allowed to submit without choosing a TA.
Instructor: Jennifer Marie Schmidt  Jenny was always prepared, honest, and excited to be there. This made discussion group productive and fun.

Instructor: Jennifer Marie Schmidt  Jenny was always accessible and a welcoming presence as a discussion leader. Sometimes though, we looked to her for more context and direction than she provided. Jenny was at her best when she brought in other work of the period studied (like music), and when she pushed the discussion toward imagining the work in production or how we would produce it today. She should play to her strengths and prepare more activities along these lines. The more academic discussions this semester were less valuable. Similarly, her weekly writing questions were best when clearly designed to get the juices flowing for discussion. Sometimes it was clear in class that that was the intention, but the written question had seemed very specific or technical. I think making it clear that the question and the discussion are designed together would help students be more excited and engaged.
Instructor: Jennifer Marie Schmidt  Ms. Schmidt is kind and encouraging, but was seemed confused by most questions that didn't have to do directly with her personal expertise.
Instructor: Kee-Yoon Nahm  Kee-Yoon is great and clearly ready to be a teacher.
Instructor: Lauren East Dubowski  Lauren did an excellent job at allowing our discussion sections to tend to the interests of the students, as related to the readings/lectures.
